Name: Shabti of Ankhpefhery
Description: Faience shabti with blue-green glaze, for a man named Ankhpefhery. The figure has a long false beard, symbol of divinity, and a plain tripartite wig with long lappets. The hands are crossed over the chest and hold a pick and hoe. The back-pillar of the figure is not inscribed. This is one of a set found at el-Hiba, a major strategic town in Middle Egypt in the first millennium BC. Hundreds of shabtis might be placed in each rich burial at this date. The hieroglyphic text over the front and sides of the figure specify that it was intended to carry out any hard labour for the deceased in the next life.
